Taste: Curry was good but spice level wasn't spicy enough. Takoyaki was pretty good as well.

They have a parking lot. Portion was good that I was able to split one plate with a friend.
I really like this place. I need to go more often. For some reason it's nvr too crowded but that's a good thing. Wish they had beer as well.

Food: excellent, SUPER AUTHENTIC japanese chicken katsu curry, original spice level, with croquette added. Hubby likes spice level 5. If you want the red pickled radish and pickled onions, you need to ask for it (complimentary), otherwise it does not come on the plate even though it is pictured on the menu. I don't know why they don't just put it on the plate, maybe people don't eat it and food is wasted? The chicken is fried perfectly, super moist on the outside and panko crispy on the outside. Yum - I want to eat here every week!

Authenticity: Japanese run. Feels liked I've stepped into a restaurant in Tokyo. 

Parking: small lot competing with other popular restaurants, so go at off times!

Service: Attentive and friendly.

Great little spot for Japanese style curry!  Love how you can adjust spice level and the selection of toppings is great.  Usually stick to the pork Katsu curry with a side of steamed vegetables.  The aroma of curry as you enter is quite pungent and gets your appetite going even more.  The pork tender katsu curry is very good but I tend to just gravitate back to the standard katsu curry.  The appetizers are good to try family style especially if you order a curry entree.  Recommendations include the breaded oysters, shumai and gyoza.  These aren't gourmet appetizers per say but they are quite tasty in their own rights.  The owner spends his time in the kitchen preparing dishes so you know you're in good hands during every meal here.  I've seen some people eating the curry udon and would like to try it sometime soon.

Great curry! Loved that you can have Japanese curry in Vegas.
Never thought I'd venture out of the strip but it is totally worth the annoying drive down the LV Boulevard to Chinatown for good eats.
They do fried stuff right. My Tonkatsu curry was fried well and still not tough to eat. They offer different levels of spiciness (from 1 to 100). I've had the level 5 - thought it was spicy enough! My hubs had level 10 yet he didn't feel the heat. 
Service was prompt & friendly.
The kaki fry was yummy~ takoyaki is standard.
So grab a cold draft and enjoy the fried goods and some tasty curry!!
I had never tasted the curry, but is rich i love this place, the guys are so friendly

I was pretty excited to try this place since I love curry, but I think it was just okay. I actual prefer the curry that you can buy in boxes at the supermarket and make at home way more.

I ordered a vegetable curry with low spicy level. They were pretty generous with the veggies, which was nice. The curry sauce was pretty thick, which I think is what it's supposed to be. Unfortunately I didn't like it being so thick and heavy.

It's not bad, but I think there are better food options around. My friends seemed to enjoy it so if you really like curry then stop by.

It was good, the menu is very simple and very straight forward. The service was excellent and quick, but everything is fried on their menu. While this place does not beat my favorite curry at Sushi Hiro, it is good for a quick fix.

We arrived on a Tuesday night about 8pm and there was no wait and probably about three tables available. Small, quint restaurant. 

The menu is pretty simple. I chose the katsu chicken curry with spinach and it was super yummy! We also ordered the takoyaki appetizer which my friend and I both enjoyed. 

I only deduct one star because we received our entrees before our appetizer that I actually almost forgot about until my friend mentioned something.

This place was fantastic. Some of the best Japanese curry I've ever had. Though, I would say that a 4 on their heat scale is maybe hotter than I would have thought a 4 would be ;) Get one of the croquettes: they're perfectly crisp on the outside and delightfully fluffy inside.

THE BEST I'VE HAD!!
Takiyaki balls and curry katsu with cheese and sausages. 'Nuff said! Vegas isn't all about the buffets anymore. The best restaurants are off strip, and this one is a must eat! I hate to see the line gets longer, but I have say this is one of the best foods I've had. My friends and I went there years ago. I took my parents there. I took my fiancee there. Then I returned with my fiancee and my friends. Would I go again? Yes, I'll make sure to go here whenever I'm in Vegas.

I love this place, I told my friend I had an urge for Curry and she suggested this place.  This was her go to place and I can see why.  Its only sad because Seattle doesn't have an establishment like this.  Anyways, during my trip, I came here twice and was blown away by the curry.  The heat rating system was new to me since it went it to 10.  I had 7 twice and might actually bump up to 10 next time!  Both times, I got vegetable curry with some sort of protein.  My favorite would have to be the beef since I like stewed meats.  This with the sides of almond slivers, pickles veg.  I feel refuel and  ready to tackle the Sin City again.

Simply the best! I always get chicken Katsu curry with veggies spicy level 5. So goood. Service is great and you're greeted arriving and leaving which is nice. I wish I lived closer so I could eat here more often!

Went Sunday 7-19-15 around 12:30 PM.  Waited outside for almost an hour.  Not an easy thing to do when you have a 1-year-old when it's 95 degrees outside.  But that's not their fault.  The place is kinda small and the "waiting list" is just a sheet of paper you have to write your own name on and they'll call you when there's a table ready.  
It's just west of Decatur on Spring Mountain. It's in the same shopping center as Monta Ramen, Kung Fu Tea, and Raku. 

I'd never had japanese curry before.  I got the chicken katsu+curry spicy level 2+corn+cheese. I left a $4 tip and the total was $15.52.  I can see why this is crave-worthy.  The only thing I can compare it to is curry-wurst in Germany.  It's like a thick brown gravy with curry in it.  The chicken was fried perfectly in a panko coating but was incredibly bland.  Maybe it's supposed to be like that to balance the strong curry.  The rice was wonderfully sticky and the cheese made the whole dish feel comforting.  

Level 2 spicy was just enough...my white girl palette can only handle so much.  It would be really good with french fries I bet.  I liked it and I'd eat it again.

I love this curry I love this curry it's yummy yummy in my tummy!

This place has expanded! It users to be a little place but glad it is growing popularity.

I just went to their pre-opening and I loved it!
I can't wait to take my husband because I know he will love it, too!

Their curry  reminds me of  a famous Japanese curry chain called CoCo Ichiban, which is my favorite curry restaurant in Japan.

I had chicken katsu (chicken cutlet) curry, which was always my favorite at CoCo.  Their secret curry sauce is prepared from scratch, and I was so impressed that theirs was as good as CoCo's! I had been missing this so much!

Along with basic curry,  you can add toppings of your choice from chicken cutlet, pork cutlet, deep fried shrimp, croquette, yakiniku beef, sausage and more. I always like chicken katsu on my curry, but other people were saying pork katsu was good, too. I think the spice level is about 4 out of 10, not too spicy, not too mild, but you can add more spice if you like.

The price was reasonable. Curry with 1 or 2 toppings(which I think is enough), is less than $10. Sometimes Japanese portions are too small, but theirs was big enough and I felt very satisfied after the meal. 

If you're missing real Japanese curry, or if you 're disappointed with others, this is the one you should try!

DEElicious chicken katsu with spinach curry!! The rakkyo and radish are must have accompaniments!! This place rivals Hurry Curry on Sawtelle!! In fact, they surprise them because they are able to titrate the spice factor 1-10!! I got 3/10 and this was the perfection a that I would beg for at Hurry Curry. Can't imagine what 5-10 would be like!! Also another plus, plus, plus is that they have Asahi on tap!! This place was sooooo good that it's still on my mind!!

This place is addicting and oh so good!  I come once a week.  I don't know why it's so addicting because the dishes are so simple, but it truly is.  Last time I sat in the bar directly in front of the kitchen and I was pleased to see that the kitchen was spotless and the cooks were handling the good properly.  My only complaints are that the benches are uncomfortable (needs better cushions) and some do the servers can't communicate in English that well.  But it's not a big deal.

Yaaaasssss! HAPPINESS IN MY TUMMY!! Talk about a great place with amazing selections. Their curry is delicious.. I really mean it! They cook their curry in a vegetable broth so it is definitely vegetarian friendly here. I wouldn't say vegan because they might fry their Katsu chicken in the same oil as the tofu style katsu. 

You can customize your level of spice here. I normally just get level 3 for my curry because it has a perfect mild kick. The Chicken Katsu is delicious but my favorite is the tofu style. Great flavor!! Amazing crunch!! You can add veggies, cheese and all these other toppings on your dish. They also serve 16 grain rice there which if you are a brown rice lover, its such a great option to have! Very healthy and delicious. 

The servers are soooooo nice here! They quick and come around often to refill your drinks and to check on you. They train them well! I recommend this place if you love Japanese curry. You'll be really happy!! Cheers!

this is a good place to eat whenever you want something quick, filling, decently good price. they charge extra for spice in the curry, which goes higher as the spice increases. my favorite is deep fried shrimp and no spice since i don't like hot/spicy sauces. my boyfriend likes to get the original chicken katsu ($8.95) which is cheaper than the deep fried shrimp ($10.45). they have a good variety of food on their menu. 
the restaurant is somewhat small but the most i've ever waited to be seated is 15 minutes. i always come here whenever i want something good but cheap!

It's a really small place in the same plaza as Monta Ramen. Very tiny but still nice. I'm actually not a curry person. I gave it a try and it was surprisingly good. I think I'll be a fan of curry now. I went tonight because I was randomly craving some of their curry when I was at work. I guess it's definitely pretty worthwhile if it gave me a random craving!

The curry mixture was tasty and pretty addicting, if I do say so myself. I've had both the chicken and the pork curry. Meat isn't the best or anything but the curry makes up for it.

I'm looking forward to trying their curry dog next time.

Staff is VERY nice and polite. Mucho friendly :). My friend says it's the closest you can get to Japanese curry! That's absolutely promising to hear!

Very enjoyable food. I had a lunch, with the spinach curry with egg and three skewers; the chicken and zucchini were my favorite of the two. Filling and tasty. Service is friendly, not the fastest, but friendly. I'd definitely recommend it for a taste of a different type of Japanese food than many people in the US are used to having.

There is a part of me that wishes I could live in japan and drive the insanely awesome vehicles that they produce, date all the hot woman that they have and specially eat all the awesome food that this country comes up with. Sadly I am not there..but places like curry zen makes me feel a little better

I could spend days explaining the taste of this place, and it would not compare to the experience at all. This place is simply magnificent. The quality, the presentation and the flavor are out of this world and to top that the service , courtesy and warmth of the servers and chefs make this one of my new favorite spots.

The spot is small but thankfully ive never had to spend time waiting. Maybe its because the damn hipsters haven't find this yet and I am cool with that !.

The pork is so tender and the curry is thick with a decent amount of rice as well.Be sure to try the enderloin at least once.If it feels a little too expensive for you, stay with the chicken if you want..it still tastes epic. If you lke it hot they wont change it while cooking however you get the spices in the table. Not a biggie..I like getting the legit thing so not altering it actually works for me.

Everytime I went my glass was NEVER empty and had the staff checking for satisfaction all the time. Seriously the service was better than most 5 star restaurants..and why? Because they were sincere!! You can see them wanting you to enjoy.. that my foodies; is priceless .

Want to know what is the hardest thing for me to do? Go to that plaza..sit down in my car and look at monta...look at zen..look at monta again..zen one more time.. MY HEAD WILL EXPLODE one of these days. I need to figure a system out.. It is like going to a strip club and have "destiny" and "charity" (classic stripper names btw) offering you buy one get 2 free!! DON'T JUDGE ME.

Do yourself a favor and try it. Get that JDM hotness in you and you wont be able to let go!

So apparently this little strip mall called Seoul Plaza is the Asian Food mecca of Las Vegas...  There are no less than 5 outstanding restaurants in this mall according to Yelp - the already famous Raku; Kabuto which some claim is the best sushi in town; the unique-in-Vegas Trattoria Nakamura-Ya; Monta Ramen which had lines waiting to be seated; Big Wong's representing Asian street food culture, and the little gem that is Japanese Curry Zen.  I guess jury is still out on Chung Gi Wa, a Korean restaurant that translates to Blue Roof, since I can't find a Yelp review on it.

We were really looking for a donkatsu place (can anyone suggest a good one in Vegas?), and found this place around the corner from where we were.  Not exactly a katsu joint, but we like curry so decided to give it a try.  4.5 stars on 270+ reviews can't be wrong, right?  Well, the only thing I'm wondering at this point is - what happened to the other .5 star?  Because honestly this is the best curry I've ever had.  I am quickly realizing that Vegas has L.A. beat when it comes to Japanese food not named sushi.  Only if Udon West (NYC joint with the absolute greatest gyu don ever)  came to the West...

Anyway, upon walk-in you are greeted by practically everyone working there - including the older gentleman behind the counter who appears to be the owner-chef.  The all-male crew is super friendly, attentive, and speedy.  The décor is simple clean.  Domestic beer is $2.50.  Off to a good start.  We order a curry pan, a katsu curry and a shrimp curry.  Curry pan comes in literally 2 minutes, and it's piping hot (on a side note, I realized then that "pan" is Japanese for bread - which I should have guessed because "ppang" is Korean for bread...).  And this thing is AMAZING good.  Koreans call this croquette, but none that I've had in a Korean bakery comes anywhere close to this little piece of addiction.  I should have gotten 3 more of these and called it a day.  But then, I would have missed out on their equally amazing curry.

The curry dishes come 5 minutes later, and I'm initially a bit disappointed.  3 smallish pieces of fried shrimp with a lot of rice and curry sauce.  A smallish piece of donkatsu with a lot of rice and curry sauce.  No side dishes, veggies, nothing.  At $9.50 per, I was expecting Wako size I guess.  I force myself to recall that Curry House was $15, and this is not a bad deal.  A bite of the shrimp with rice on curry sauce and I'm convinced this is a good deal.  Perfectly fried shrimp and pork with perfectly cooked rice smothered in the BEST curry sauce ever.  And 20 minutes after I've completely forgotten how small the meats were, I am full and fully satisfied.  One word of warning:  they have spicy scale of 1-10, and they recommend a 3 for those who like spicy food.  I would heed those recommendations!

So after a beer, bottle of water, appetizer and two main dishes, we get a bill for under $27.  Okay, this is a great deal.  We're coming back here over and over.  But in between, we'll have to resist the temptation and also try Raku, Kabuto, Monta, Nakamura-Ya, and Big Wong's.  Maybe Chung Gi Wa too.

Table-for-1 Factor:  There is a bar with half-dozen or so seats, behind which is where the cooking happens.  I think it's perfect for eating solo.

Not a bad pit stop if you're craving some curry and don't have a ton of cash on you. 

It's a nice quiet tiny restaurant that you imagine in Japan and the host / watier was really friendly and polite. The menu is pretty limited with specials written on the board.

The nice thing about this place is that they serve both white and brown rice and also can do half orders on rice for those who are cutting down on carbs. 

What I had to eat was the Pork Tenderloin Cutlet with Curry and Brown Rice + an additional Chicken Cutlet and Croquette. All of it was pretty good and the cutlets weren't dry at all. That with the combination of curry and rice makes the best comfort food after a long day!

I can eat here couple times a week... no joke!
Cheap... tasty... no wait... and the best katsu curry in the city hands down!
I wanted to have my fix one last time before leaving the city the other day but the electricity was down! oh well.
If you love katsu curry... this is a must!!!
My favorite gem in LV chinatown!

There's a couple of new Japanese curry cafes that have opened up in the Chinatown area of Vegas.  I was bummed that Cafe de Japon had closed down a year ago, the curry experience was one of the best I'd ever had.  This small restaurant, located in the same shopping cul-de-sac as Kung Fu Tea and a questionable Massage parlor in Chinatown is very nice and the food is very good. They have daily specials which is on the board, today's listed special curry udon, pan fried or deep fried gyoza or shumai, and a fried oysters appetizer which looked tempting.  

They had the standard Japanese curry menu with a decent amount of curry selections. I ordered the pork katsu curry, which was fairly priced at around $10, although I was tempted to order the tenderloin pork katsu. The pork katsu was really good, though nothing that exceptional and well breaded.  The curry was flavorful and sweet, though not overly.  You are able to order various levels of curry which range from .20+ depending on the level of spiciness on a scale of 1-10.  I ordered 5, which is actually pretty spicy and cost 40cents more.  If you're looking for a well rounded med spicy level, go with 3 or 4 instead.

Decent parking, good service.  Will get full especially during lunch as it's kind of small.  Recommended.

I have lived in Okinawa , Japan. Where I fell in love with a curry house called Coco's, as a child. It has legit been years since I've come close to curry that tastes like that ! This place is EVERYTHING !!! I truly recommend this place to everyone !!

We were originally shooting for Tofu Hut, but since the Golden Warriors won the NBA Finals... We decided to celebrate in honor of Steph Curry and get some curry (get it?)

My boyfriend has been to this place once before so he pretty much knew right off the bat what he wanted. I stuck to what I knew which was chicken katsu. They have a spice level scale on the bottom right hand of their menu. I can handle a little heat, but not too much - with that being said, I went with a level 3.

I can not be more thankful that I did. A level 3 was just perfect for me and my "heat" palate. It gave my meal a good kick without causing a waterfall dispensing from my nose. I do have to add though that a level 3 here is a lot more spicier than a level 3 in most Thai restaurants that I've ate at. In addition to our meals, we ordered tako yaki. It's good for what it is (octopus balls), but I probably wouldn't order it again since I'm not really a fan of octopus.

If you're a fan of curry, consider this place. It's small, quaint, and the chefs pack a hell of a punch when it comes to spices in your meals.

I ordered pork katsu curry. The pork chop was very juicy even though it was deep fried. The rice was very soft! The spicy levels are from mild, 0-10, where mild has no spice in it and zero has a kick in the spiciness. An order of curry is around $10, and the portion is small. I agreed with a lot of yelper that the curry tastes good; however, is it really worth the money you spend?! I will leave it up to you to decide.

Point is taking away because the portion is small. 

*line could be long during lunch or dinner time!

Curry Zen does their spice and katsu very well.  As others have said, level 5 is pretty good (for me) - the spicyness builds as you eat your meal.  The cool, sweet pickles make a real nice complement with every bite!  Value is okay - I would have expected a bit better value in Vegas Chinatown.  The self-serve pickles (and other curry "add-ins") are a nice touch.  Solid place that is definitely worth a visit and we will return.

I had the chicken curry here, while my friend had the katsu curry. I'm a huuuuuuuuuuuuuge curry fan, deeming it one of my last meals on this planet if the world were to end tomorrow. 

I wasn't too fond of the curry flavor. It was OK. The BEST thing that ever came out of this restaurant was the FRIED SPAM. My friend wanted to order this, and I thought he was crazy, thinking, "Do you wanna stroke or shoot up your cholesterol by double in 5 minutes?"

Sometimes the baddest things in life are oh-so-good. Fried spam was the highlight of my night. The curry was a 2 star, and the fried spam brings this place up to a 3 star. I don't know if they still have it on the menu since I had it about a year ago. Perhaps this place has improved itself since then, as I am seeing higher reviews. I shall find out again later if I visit.

While we haven't tried the other japanese curry place Zen Curry is the bomb! My family and I fell in love with this place from day 1. It's affordable and oh so yummy! Must not be high in sodium cause it doesn't raise my grandmas blood pressure like the ones you make at home from the box. It may be quick and easy, but packed with sodium! We always leave Zen Curry wanting more despite being full :D
It's one of our family's favorite spot to eat when we crave Japanese Curry! I wish the restaurant would be bigger, but it's worth the wait!
Great rice bowls...."A"grade.....Jap-Hawaiian fusion. Coffee gello and Don katsu with red ginger and nori was good! I gotta try spam cutlet and mild curry my next stop. Great service by Natia!

This was my first time trying Japanese curry so I have nothing to base it off of, but I love this place! I love the flavor of the curry. The chicken katsu is delicious!!!! I love the vegetable curry too. Perfect combo is chicken katsu and vegetables and of course with rice. I highly recommend this place. Great customer service as well. Staff is always helpful and amazing.

We hadn't had GOOD pork Katsu curry in a long time and so we decided to try Japanese Curry Zen while visiting Vegas. The wait staff and one of the cooks (we couldn't really see the whole open kitchen so we weren't sure how many cooks there were) were Japanese so we took that as a promising sign of things to come. They serve Asahi draft beer which made us happy and also Sapporo beer. We decided to order the pork tender curry with cheese topping and white rice at spicy level 3. We usually go with spicy level 8 in Japan but the waiter warned us that anything more than 5 would be extremely hot. So to be safe, we opted for level 3. We were glad that we got level 3 because that already had a kick and anything beyond that would just make the curry overpoweringly spicy and ruin the taste for us. The curry was excellent. The pork was tender and delicious. The cheese topping sealed the deal for us. We came out of Japanese Curry Zen "tummy-happy" that we found a slice of Japanese curry heaven in Vegas!

This place is legit. Japanese chef. Japanese patrons. Great prices.

I love how you can customize your basic Japanese curry plate and fix it up to your specific liking.

1, Proteins (chicken/beef/shrimp/kurobata sausage/etc) or some awesome combination using everything. (That's what I would do if I came back - have a Japanese curry plate sampler!) 
2. Spice level (1-10) 
3. Free tableside condiments (red pickles, raisins, pickled onions, ginger, curry and spice powders) Customize to your liking. 

I ordered the PORK KATSU CURRY LEVEL 5 ($9.5) and the flavor was on point. CRAVE WORTHY. Rich and complex with out being too soupy or sweet. Perfect spice level for me. (Kaba curry is more on the sweeter side). The katsu was flavorful and crisp. They just cooked it a minute longer which made it a little dry. Same with the chicken katsu, but still very good. Good sized portion too. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/japanese-curry-zen-las-vegas?select=e1MyBcsVEp6Dppyp7sZ2Tw#e1MyBcsVEp6Dppyp7sZ2Tw)

Notes
-The place is small with like 4 tables (of 4) and a counter top so I could imagine this place easily getting busy. Not really good for groups larger than 4. 
-Came on a Saturday for lunch right when they opened at 11:30am and we were the 3rd group there. 
-Have your curry topped with cheese. So good. 

Would definitely have this on rotation if I lived closer. 
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/japanese-curry-zen-las-vegas?select=zG-CdqAJWfLtywgc2FF4yQ#zG-CdqAJWfLtywgc2FF4yQ)

I've been dining here for quite some time now and Curry Zen has sustained their quality, service and efforts! From the moment I stepped into this establishment, I felt authenticity. Some may say that there's simply nothing too special about it but hey, that's your opinion. For the rest of us who do enjoy the simplicity of this place, we think of something more. To me, personally, I find comfort here. 

With excellent food comes an excellent workforce. These two elements come hand in hand to produce the overall business and Curry Zen, I would like to give you guys a round of applause. You guys are the bridge to the production of these beautifully crafted dishes.

One more thing to add on to that, the prices are affordable! So technically, not only do you get good food, you don't break the bank either! 

Overall, I encourage you first timers to have a go at this place, it definitely will not disappoint and is worth trying out. And to the rest of us who's been dining here for some time now, we all know why we keep coming back.

Nice touch on the new updated menu by the way.

I don't understand why it's 4 and a half stars. This place does not taste like real Japanese curry. I could have made a better one at home with a pre-made curry base. Even my mother in law from Japan stated that it tasted like they used pre-made powder to make the curry. The dish was not presentable either. The dish looked really plain. They didn't serve any side salad like Curry House, which they serve a small side salad and corn soup along with the curry. The service was not great either. When we arrived, we waited for over 30 minutes for a table of 3 even though there was a table of 2 open, which I didn't think we would be seated there anywase because it would not fit all three of us. When a table opened up, they split the table to serve the 3 of us and a group of 4 people that came much later. They seated us on a table that was originally for only 2 people while the group behind us sat at a bigger table that seated for 4. My husband mentioned that they could have just seated us at the other small table of 2 that was open the whole time we waited the 30 minutes rather than wait 30 minutes to be seated at a different small table of 2. We asked why we couldn't have the bigger table for 4 even though we had 3 people and they responded that they wanted to seat the bigger group at the same time as us. We waited over 30 minutes for our seats while this other group that literally came through the door waited no more than 5 minutes. I also didn't like how the waiters had to squeeze past my seat to get to the other tables because I was seated on the side of the small tiny table that was really only for table of 2. I had to squeeze myself as close to the table as possible for the waiters to have some space to pass me. I really tried my best even though I was pregnant. We had a difficult time eating at this small table with our big plates. I'm pretty clumsy so I'm glad that I didn't drop my dish or water. I will never come back to this place and I recommend that you do the same!

An hour and a half of free time? 15 minutes away from UNLV? 

I've had Japanese Curry Zen bookmarked ever since having this midnight craving for Japanese Curry and this satisfied that craving... 1 year later. 

I opted for the Chicken Cutlet (my usual) and added some medium spices and it was delicious! Our Server greeted us, gave us the option to sit (there weren't many people there at the time, but was packed by the time we left) 

Friendly staff and good food will make me a fan any day

I've been here multiple times and it's no wonder why this place gets such good reviews.

I've came here for lunch and dinner at different times and both times I didn't have to wait to be seated. The staff is friendly and definitely acknowledges the presence of their customers. Not many places do that nowadays.

The place is a bit small but it still feels very spacious. They have tables, booths, and a bar. The place also looks clean.

Their menu is pretty simple to follow if you haven't had Japanese curry before, they offer a lot of pictures of each dish. You choose the level of spiciness on your curry.

I've has the tofu katsu, pork katsu, and chicken katsu here. My favorite out of the 3 is the tofu katsu!. The curry is very flavorful. It's savory and packs a lot of heat! You can also get a non spicy curry.

Will definitely be back!

Like the ancient Chinese proverb says "it has grown on me like a colony of E. Coli".  After 3-4 visits I'm seriously digging this place. It's is relatively "healthy", delicious, fast and affordable. Not to mention that is one of the cleanest Japanese spots In the area. 

Menu is very limited with few protein variations of the same rice and curry plate. There are few toppings or add ons. I have tried chicken katsu and pork cutlet with croquette toppings. I really like the condiments: almonds, sweet onions and radish. You can also request brown rice as a side. 

I've tried the tofu dessert, also very tasty. 

Seoul Plaza has to be the one of the foodiest spots in the city. Add JCZ to the list.

Some of the best food I have ever had. The staff is always very welcoming and everything on the menu is delicious. Plus the renovations really made the place so much more open, which makes it a lot easier to get in!

This little hidden spot gets passed over a lot since it's in the same shopping plaza with some off-strip heavy hitters like Monta Ramen, Raku, Raku Sweets, and Kung Fu Tea. I've been wanting to try this place for awhile and finally did. The Japanese curry is stick and creamy in texture but still getting that hint of spice (you can get it spicier if you want). I love the katsu toppings - I got chicken and a croquette. Both were crunchy and crispy on the outside but moist (and the chicken was tender) on the inside. I've never had spinach incorporated into my curry sauce but I really liked it (but I also really like spinach)! I don't think I can go back to just plane curry. Service was fast and friendly!

I have been a customer of Zen since it opened. My friends and I would often come here because we wanted to support the restaurant, so I'm really glad that it is as successful as I would have imagined it to be.

There aren't many specialty restaurants in Vegas that have Japanese curry as their selling point and that's why I think Curry Zen is good for Vegas. It is unique and it is different from what we already have here. If you've never tried Japanese curry before, I say go here for your first time. The curry sauce is creamy and very tasteful and the way they cook their meat is perfection. This is definitely authentic Japanese curry. I've been to Japan a few times before and when I eat curry there, it reminds me of Curry Zen and makes me miss the restaurant. They have a bigger selection of Japanese curry now (as compared to when they started when they only have about 10-15 dishes) so you'll definitely find something that you like. The customer service here is as good as it gets as well. Sure, it gets busy from time to time and they forget to refill your water but you can see genuine smiles from the server that never seem to disappear. The owners also walk around to see how you are doing, which I think makes it such a personal and inviting restaurant. 

They have a nice selection of desserts and non-curry food as well, so if you're not into Japanese curry, you can always try other selections that they have.

All in all, Curry Zen is definitely worth a shot. If you've never been here before, try it. I'm sure you'll be a regular like me before you know it.

Love it best curry place I've tried in years,I been to several other places but none compare 

Try the pork tender curry

They have really good curry! I got the regular katsu curry. My friends all got 2 or higher and they said it was pretty spicy! If you like spicy, they have a scale that goes all the way up to 10 and apparently it's really spicy! Their place is small, cute, and clean. Their staff is really nice and I would recommend this place if you want to eat curry! I don't eat curry on the daily but they're pretty much the place everyone tells me to go to! So try it out if you want to try something new!
One of my wife's favorites. I am a fan of the curry with basically anything. Japanese curry very different then other curries. Still amazing though.

I'm not really into Curry that much but when I'm in the mood, Zen Curry is the place to go! One of the best locations to get curry and rice in my opinion. My all time fav is the chicken katsu with rice and curry. Recently one of my friends recommended adding cheese with my order and I was a bit skeptical at first but after one bite, I was in love. Gotta try it with cheese man 

Afterwords if you're in the mood for boba, guess what's around the corner? Kung Fu Tea. Oh my G!

Real Japanese curry made by real Japanese people! 
I always do a happy dance inside when I encounter this..

Just like in Japan, most restaurants the menu's are small and specialize in one type of dish; in this case curry. 

Food Breakdown:
I ordered tonkatsu curry. 
The curry sauce itself is legit Japanese curry and was mild in spice and flavor. 
They did offer pepper and other spices if you wanted to give it more oomph. This was different from the typical Nihon Curry-ya where they would ask you your spice (pain) tolerance level and add oomph accordingly. Boo on that :( 
The curry had no sustenance; just sauce. A little carrots, onions or meat in the sauce would've gone a long way in my book. 

I don't mind paying good money for good food however at a pricepoint of $9 for katsu curry it fell short and I left hungry. 

I am glad to find a legit nihon curry-ya in Vegas so I'm sure I'll be back.

When is Debra going to learn? When you see the name of the food they serve in the name of the place, then that is what you should be ordering. I don't know when I am going to learn.

I went with their dish that did not have curry. I can't recall the name right now but it was a pork katsu bowl with rice, eggs, seaweed and ginger. I loved the ginger in the bowl. Barely any seaweed. And the scrambled egg, was somewhere in between cooked and not cooked. No complaints from me though, I thought at first I can dig this. 

Then I had to dig out a piece of a hair that was embedded in my pork katsu. It was mixed in with the batter surrounding the pork and it never seemed to end. I didn't complain. I just pushed my bowl to the side and ate no more.

Overall, I left feeling disgusted and sad. Even with the hair experience, me and my coworker said we would return but only to try to the Curry. I am not just not sure how fast that is going to happen for me.

Pretty good, we ordered chicken katsu curry with potato croquette (they say "cro-que" but that sounds like the lawn game), takoyaki, and iced Thai teas and added a level 8  extra curry sauce.  

Tako Yaki - fried octopus & seaweed, mayo and tonkatsu sauce - not for typical Western palates nor those who don't like squishy hot fishy seaweed taste. 

The curry is good. There are extra powdered spices at the table, cayenne and masala curry. 

Service is excellent the 2 times we went there. We were seated immediately. Drink orders we taken and filled fast. 

My Japanese college roommates loved coming to Las Vegas because there was real and typical Japanese food made by Japanese chefs. This is one of those places.

A girlfriend and I decided to stop here before the flight back home. We weren't hungry when we first walked in, in fact we didn't even plan on eating.

But the nostalgic scent of curry in the air...oh man...it sat us right now.

She ordered some katsu curry and I ordered a vegetable curry. Again, I wasn't hungry. Once I had a bite of that curry-drizzled rice, I couldn't stahp!!

The food was delicious! I licked my plate clean and best of all...their water was fresh. (You know some restaurants just serve you tap water, this place was refreshing).

I can't wait to go back! Seriously, great food in Las Vegas is often found off the strip!

The chicken katsu was tender and perfectly fried. The pork katsu was a little hard to chew however. Mild 4 was not even spicy at all but still good. They have options for brown rice but no veggies included on your meal. Takoyaki was bomb! Place is clean and modern. Service was fast as well. Dont mind coming back here again.

I imagine this is about as good as pork katzu and curry can get so in that regard it could be five stars.  My favorite part of the meal was seeing you could get food from 1-10 spicy level but 6-10 cost extra.  I assumed 5 couldn't be that spicy but the waiter warned me against it.  3 ended up being about perfect.  

I'll have to trick a friend into getting an 8 or 9 some time.  In the name of science, of course.

The first time I came here, it was a full house at this tiny restaurant. There were also many people waiting outside, so we left and decided to come back another time. Our second visit happened around noon on a Friday. While we were driving here, I thought for sure it would be packed again. To my surprise, there were several open seats. I guess it was a great idea to come here on iPad Mini launch day!

As I mentioned, this place is very tiny. There are 18 seats available (yes, I actually counted, lol). Two tables that seats 4, one table that seats 2, and 8 seats at the bar. The menu is tiny as well, with only 6 toppings to choose from. I appreciate that they have brown rice and don't charge extra for it. Ordered my usual - Chicken Cutlet Curry. The curry was full of flavor and not too watery or salty. Portion size of the chicken cutlet was perfect and not too small. 

Service was a bit slow. The place filled up eventually and there was only one server. We had to wait a while for our bill after our plates were taken away. 

Simple menu, tasty, filling, and inexpensive. I'll be back for sure, but maybe for take-out since it is always crowded here. Hopefully they will open a second, bigger location in the future. 

FYI - minimum credit card charge is $8.00.

Since starting at UNLV almost three years ago, I have come here probably 30 times. I love their curry, especially the curry udon. I also love their katsu-don! Definitely would recommend it to anyone who loves Japanese-style curry or just Japanese food in general.

I believe you need a lot of sophistication to enjoy Japanese Curry. It's just these small little differences with the spices that separates  a J-Curry place from being "good" and "great". And, I believe that JAPANESE CURRY ZENBAYASHI has achieved Greatness. 

This is a rare Japanese restaurant where they pay attention to the smallest details. For example, today the Rakkyo was perfectly cut in a distinct geometric style, which made every single piece look identical in size and shape. At first, I thought I was seeing things but eventually after watching Mr. Zenbayashi working so carefully in the kitchen, I came the conclusion that they spend hours before the store opens preparing everything to look beautiful and artistic.

Unlike similar restaurants, JCZ will refrigerate the condiments such as Tonkatsu Sauce, Rakkyo, and Fukujinzuke. They wait till a customer arrives and then they bring them out with new clean serving spoons. Other places around town will merely keep the condiments sitting out on the table all day long with the same serving spoons which had been touched by many dirty hands. But, you won't find that problem here. This is the most spotless and clean restaurant I have seen in Las Vegas.  Even the bathroom looked like no one had ever used it. 

Just like INABA, this place prides itself on having a dish that not only tastes great, but has tons of health benefits. They have a homemade Gram Masala which is a combination of about 15 spices such as Turmeric, Coriander, Black Pepper, Cumin, Cardamom, Fennel, Japanese Chili Pepper, Ginger, Garlic, Paprika, and many more. Unlike Indian Curry, J-Curry is lower in calories and fat content. It also has anti-oxidents, digestive benefits, blood cleansing, and even anti-aging benefits. 

I actually came here by accident today, I spent most of the day loitering at Jen G's place of work.  After about 3 hours of bugging her, she told me to "BUY SOMETHING OR GET OUT!", so I went straight to JCZ! ...Just kidding. Actually, the true story does involve me loitering at Jen G's place of employment, but we had a conversation about Kabuto, and both of us agreed we should go there and give it another try. I actually didn't like my last visit to Kabuto on account of being spoiled by Urusawa in LA. But, I ended up going over there anyway  to make a reservation. While I was in the parking lot, I noticed the JCZ sign.  David Y had recommended the place to me earlier, and he told me that it was exactly what he used to get in Japan, so I gave it a try. And Dave was right, it was the best. I don't know why people would rather eat at overrated Monta when JAPANESE CURRY ZEN is only a 15 second walk. And the best part of JCZ is that it doesn't have a 2 hour waiting list, uncomfortable seating, overflowing toilet, hipsters and emos reciting poetry, and non-japanese cooks who cook the eggs in the back alley(read my review on Monta to understand that better). And that's another thing that makes JCZ great, it's 100% Japanese staffed. Sure, I actually know Chinese and Filipino Sushi Chefs who make some Japanese ones look like amateurs, but the point is that it's always so unique to find a J-restaurant that is 100% Japanese staffed.

The best thing on the menu is the Pork Tenderloin Curry. Do not confuse this with the normal Pork Cutlet. The Pork Tenderloin Curry will not be on the main menu. You have to ask for it specifically. Today, the cook put so much attention into making sure the cutlet was fried perfectly. The color was beautifully golden brown, and the texture of the meat was so juicy and soft that I ended up eating it all in less than 5 minutes. 

This was the best service I have ever had as a 1st timer. Sure, there are some Japanese owned restaurants that treat me better, but that's because I've spent a lot of money there. For example, when I walk into "Sushi on Rainbow", it's like that scene in "Goodfellas" when Robert De Niro walks into the club and everyone knows his name, they open the door for him, save him  his usual seat, and everyone gets whatever he wants before he even has to ask. That's how good some places treat me because I show up regularly, I treat older Japanese workers with a lot of respect,  and because I'm f*cking rich I tend to leave giant tips. But, even though this was my first time at JAPANESE CURRY ZEN, they already were treating me like I had spent over $1000 here. And of course, even though I only spent like $10.00 on curry I left a $20 tip. And the server earned every penny of that because it really was the best service I've had in years. 

JAPANESE ZEN CURRY is a small independent business, not a million dollar bankrolled J-restaurant. Even though there is a rumor that this place is owned by the Mon-group, the server told me that it's just not true. This is a small business that needs the support of the Japanese-American community here in Las Vegas. So, I encourage all LV Japanese residents to come try this place out and support them.

Japanese Curry Zen. I've never eaten Japanese curry before, so I decided to try it for the first time at this highly-rated establishment. The photos of white rice and brown curry on plain white plates did not stimulate my appetite (slightly unappetizing looking), however, those 150 Yelpers before me could not all be wrong. For our late lunch, we shared a regular-size order of rice and curry (spice level 0) with the 5 piece Kushi Curry option. I'm not sure of the "right" way to eat curry, so I mixed together the rice and curry slurry and dug in. Mmm. Wow, it's really very yummy, a fantastic combination of spices. The skewers of fried goodies were all pretty good too. I really liked the potato croquette. It was something like mashed potatoes rolled in an egg mixture and coated with panko, then lovingly lowered it into the deep fryer. The panko-coated fried quail eggs were slightly rubbery and had a green-grey tinge around the yolk, but no biggie. Most people boil the heck out of eggs. 

Yelp did me right. Thank you! 
*Low prices 
*Filling, low-brow tasty Asian fare
*Nice service
*Tiny hole in the wall with a few bar stools and (three?) small tables, so try to come at off-peak meal times. The tables seat four, so when a group of six came in, they stood in the middle of the restaurant and watched the two parties of two eat their food. Awkward! I wouldn't mind some breathing room to scarf down my lunch... :P

So, came here today in craving for curry pan.  I have looked high and low for great Japanese curry pan and I think I found it here.  The pan was almost as good as the one I get in Little Tokyo in LA.  I also like their croquette too, not greasy at all... delicious.  I also tried their pork katsu curry and the curry was excellent.  They have great customer service and now I have a place to get curry pan when I have the craving.  Come check this place out if you love curry.  

Happy yelping xoxoxoxox

I have passed this place multiple times... and my family loves curry so they're particular where to eat. We finally gave it a try and I must say we loved it! It's a small restaurant, neat, clean, good service, and good food! We had a great time! No complaint. But It would of been nice to see or have someone at the front greeting us to wait to be seated.

One can get their fill of spicy Japanese curry here. A wide selection of toppings to choose from, but simple enough to order quickly. On a spicy scale from 1-5, I recommend 3 or under to satisfy your craving for spicy goodness. Get 4 or higher if you brought your own napkins for your nose. Satisfying they are. I'll be back when I'm in this area again.

Family recommended that we try this place out cause we just might like it.  Went to their location on Spring Mountain Rd., and this restaurant was tiny with seats for about 18 people.  Fortunately, we were there at an odd time so there was no waiting for a table.

The food was terrific, and it was presented very nicely on the plate.  Curry sauce is the best that I have ever had.  The mixture of all their various spices creates an explosion of yummy flavor!  Their was an insert at our table, and I enjoyed reading all the health benefits that the different spices offer.  Very educational.  Also liked that you choose how spicy you want your curry to be.  The scale ranges from 1 (not spicy) to 10 (their spiciest choice).  I chose the #3 level, and it had a good kick for my taste buds.  

I am happy that we were referred to Japanese Curry Zen.  If I lived in Las Vegas, they would be part of my dining out rotation.  Very very nice option!

Love this place, parking can be a pain in the ass, but I just park at the church across the street and walk in. Service is great, food is awesome. Would be 5 stars but they are a little weak on sides when you take food to go.
Delicious! Really excellent curries,  with a good number of selections. I'd suggest keeping your spice level below a 7. I normally like spicy food,  and the 7 was just at the edge of my tolerance!
This place makes me feel like I'm at home. The food is amazing and everything is made to perfection. I usually eat the shrimp tempura with a spicy #2 and that does the job for me!
